headline: Ichiro, 39, Gets Two-Year Deal
summary: The Yankees re-sign the rightfielder for two years, $13 million.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Smith & Wesson: America's Gun Maker
summary: At 160 years old, Smith & Wesson has long symbolized the American gun culture and was the weapon of choice for Clint Eastwood in the 1971 film 'Dirty Harry.'

headline: Apple Feels Heat in Brazil Over iPhone Brand
summary: A Brazilian electronics maker, IGB Eletrônica, known by its brand name Gradiente, this week launched a smartphone called the "IPHONE Neo One." The company suggested it would go after Apple for copyright infringement.

headline: BOJ, Under Pressure, Takes Action
summary: The Bank of Japan decided to take additional easing measures Thursday, after an unusually intense campaign by the incoming prime minister demanding policy makers step up their fight against deflation.

headline: Allscripts Changes CEOs
summary: Embattled electronic health-records firm Allscripts Healthcare Solutions said board member Paul Black is taking over as chief executive, succeeding longtime CEO Glen Tullman, and that the company has decided against a deal for the business.

headline: Caravaggio in Context
summary: Everyone is calling this "The Caravaggio Show," the first exhibition of its kind in California.

headline: It Looks Like Tebow Has Had Enough
summary: With Greg McElroy replacing Mark Sanchez at quarterback, Tim Tebow's confusing and unproductive tenure in New York is coming to a close.

headline: Documents May Boost Civil Suits
summary: The fines levied against UBS AG over attempts to manipulate interest rates could ultimately pale in comparison to the bill the Swiss firm and other rate-setting banks may face from private civil litigation.

headline: Who's On Strike Today?
summary: Strikes, work slowdowns and protest marches have become so common in crisis-hit Greece that it can be hard to keep track of who is demonstrating when, where and against what.

headline: Like Old Times for the Knicks
summary: In the teams' third matchup, the Knicks' Carmelo Anthony and Tyson Chandler handle the Brooklyn Nets.

headline: Rush to Close on Properties by Year-End
summary: In Manhattan, property owners are racing to beat tax increases on the rich set to take effect Jan. 1. Some deals are even designed to fall apart if they haven't closed before the ball drops in Times Square.

headline: Israel Grapples With Too Much Fashion
summary: Israel's fashion industry, which struggled for years without a marquee fashion week to attract international designers and press, is suddenly grappling with two of them.

headline: Nets, Williams Hurt by Mistakes
summary: Deron Williams is looking for answers as the Nets continue to slide.

headline: Pushback for 'Plan B'
summary: House Republicans hustled to build support for Boehner's "Plan B," which would extend Bush-era tax cuts for incomes under $1 million. Democrats rejected the plan.

headline: Upstart in Talks to Buy Rival NYSE
summary: NYSE Euronext is in talks to sell itself to rival IntercontinentalExchange Inc. for about $8 billion, in a deal that would end more than two centuries of independence for the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Marathon Deal Nears the Finish
summary: Organizers of the New York City Marathon have reached a multimillion-dollar settlement for the cancellation of last month's race, according to people with knowledge of the process.

headline: With Lhota, GOP Facing Mayoral Fray
summary: Joseph Lhota's decision to step down from his post atop the MTA to explore a run for mayor doesn't appear likely to immediately clear the GOP field.

headline: Groups Challenge N.J. Over Beach Access

headline: Page Turner at the Public
summary: The Library opened at the Public Theater at the beginning of October, as part of the theater's recent $40 million renovation.

headline: Job-Creation Awards Made in N.Y.
summary: More than $738 million in state economic development grants were awarded for projects with the potential to create jobs, with much of the funding going to regions outside of New York City with smaller populations.

headline: Related Wins Refund Case
summary: A federal appeals panel allowed developer Related Cos. to keep a $510,000 deposit from a Greek couple who had signed a contract in 2008 for a $3.4 million apartment.

headline: Hanukkah's Crafty Days and Crazy Nights
summary: In an already muted and sobering holiday season, it was easy to blink and miss Hanukkah this year, especially because those eight crazy nights came so early.

headline: A Twist for the Holidays
summary: On Thursday, Dee Snider, the frontman of the heavy-metal band Twisted Sister, will make his New York cabaret debut in the first of two shows at 54 Below, the cabaret space underneath Studio 54.

headline: From Bulls and Bears to Big Bird
summary: To the Rescue! Gala, a fundraiser for the Humane Society of the U. S.'s Animal Rescue Team, was held Tuesday night.

headline: Russia Moves Ahead With U.S. Adoption Ban
summary: Russia's lower house of parliament gave preliminary approval to a measure banning Americans from adopting Russian orphans. The move is viewed as retaliation against new U.S. restrictions on violators of human rights.

summary: This week in repertory film: Pier Paolo Pasolini, Jonas Mekas Turns 90!, and more.

headline: Musical Interlude For World's End
summary: Swirling rumors of a doomsday prophecy that the world will end Friday have driven politicians to issue rebuttals and scientists to issue evidence. Now, one group of New York musicians is taking a different action.

summary: The defending Super Bowl champs have struggled executing one of the game's most basic skills: tackling.

summary: Brazilian-Mexican consortium Braskem-Idesa said it has secured $3.2 billion in financing for a major petrochemicals project in southeastern Mexico.

summary: General Motors will purchase 200 million shares of its stock held by the U.S. Treasury in a first step toward the government's exit from the auto maker.

headline: Image Remake Suffers Hit at Deutsche

headline: Nike Struggling to Regain Its Glory Days
summary: Nike has been looking awfully mortal lately, lagging behind the Standard & Poor's 500 by 14 percentage points in the past year over concerns such as costs, currency fluctuations and slowing economies abroad.

summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Caravaggio in Context
summary: Everyone is calling this "The Caravaggio Show," the first exhibition of its kind in California.

summary: Fashion columnist Teri Agins on the ins and outs of store returns.

headline: The Best Style Books
summary: The latest crop offers a master class in chic.

headline: MAC Teams Can't Bowl
summary: When Ball State takes on Central Florida in Friday's Beef 'O' Brady's Bowl, it probably won't go down very well for the Cardinals of the Mid-American Conference.

headline: English Fans Take a Stand
summary: English soccer has dealt with its fair share of problematic fans over the years but a different kind of fan group has been making its voice heard in recent months: those who would rather not sit down.

headline: The Agony and the Jets-tasy
summary: This is a column about a 6-8 football team that failed to make the playoffs. This is a column about the New York Jets, the most entertaining team in football.

headline: Teen Smoking Keeps Falling
summary: Cigarette use among U.S. teenagers fell to historic lows and a four-year rise in marijuana use appears to have leveled off, according to a national study.

summary: Dewar's is taking Scotch advertising out of the leather-bound library and placing it in the hands of an actress wearing little more than a smoldering expression.

summary: U.S. prosecutors on Wednesday charged former UBS trader Tom Alexander William Hayes with conspiracy, wire fraud and price fixing.

headline: The Short Path to First Class
summary: Reaching the pinnacle of perks for frequent flying may not be as difficult as you think.

headline: State's Strict Laws at Odds With a Culture of Weapons
summary: Connecticut has some of the strictest gun laws in the nation, yet it also has a strong gun culture, especially in its rural areas and small towns.

summary: How Lego's designers create an elaborate fantasy world with a limited set of plastic bricks.

headline: Gun Lobby Poses Hurdle for Obama
summary: Obama directed his administration to draw up gun-control proposals in response to the Connecticut shooting, but efforts are likely to meet strong political and lobbying resistance.

summary: They are known as 'never events'—the kind of mistake that should never happen in surgery, like operating on the wrong patient or sewing someone up with a sponge still inside—and new research suggests that they happen with alarming frequency.

summary: Allies of former Sen. Chuck Hagel are pushing back at critics who question his views on Israel and the Middle East, in hopes of keeping on track his possible nomination to become secretary of defense.

summary: New research finds that rock and pop stars are at significantly greater risk of premature death than the general population. And solo performers were twice as likely to die early as members of a group were.

headline: Smith & Wesson CEO Enters Tricky Terrain
summary: Before shootings, Smith & Wesson CEO P. James Debney sought to introduce more sophisticated marketing.

headline: Holiday Sprucing for the Littlest Room
summary: Designer Celerie Kemble offers tips for how to warm up one of the most essential--and overlooked—spaces in your home: the powder room.

headline: Apple 'Pinch to Zoom'  Patent Rejected
summary: The U.S. patent office issued a preliminary ruling against Apple's "pinch to zoom" patent, which Apple used as a cornerstone of its case against Samsung.

summary: Government loans to students and banks should help markets, not supplant them.

headline: The Doomsday Sales Boom
summary: Business is booming for companies that sell survival gear, freeze-dried food and underground bunkers ahead of the Mayan calendar's predictions of the end of the world on Dec. 21, as well as other doomsday scenarios.

headline: Madoff Victims Seek Harsh Sentence for Brother

headline: Chávez Backers Lukewarm on Successor
summary: In the days since President Hugo Chávez underwent emergency surgery in Cuba to treat a recurrence of his cancer, his supporters have gathered for candlelight vigils and prayed for the health of their charismatic leader.

headline: Africa Joins Space Race
summary: A handful of nations in sub-Saharan Africa have set sights on building a space-exploration industry, inspired by economic growth that is generating new funds.

summary: A new posthumous three-disc release captures in full bloom the talents of alto saxophonist Thomas Chapin.

summary: Russia's 1998 debt default left thousands of investors nursing huge losses. Now, money managers are about to get a chance to re-enter a market that offers high returns but also political and financial risks.

summary: Barcelona's manager again faces cancer; Arsenal looks to a more British future; and Balotelli agrees to pay up.

headline: 4 at State Dept. Resign After Libya Report

headline: Boehner Plays a Weak Hand Well
summary: His 'Plan B' is an imperfect but responsible attempt to resolve the looming tax increases.

headline: Henninger: No Guardrails, Again

headline: How Did Those 'Ugly Dolls' Come to Be? Their Creators Explain
summary: The ubiquitous 'ugly dolls' got an unexpected start in a 2001 love letter. Since then, the husband-wife team behind the Pretty Ugly brand have honed their entrepreneurial approach.

headline: Icahn Bumps Up Offer for Greenbrier
summary: Carl Icahn's effort to merge American Railcar with larger rival Greenbrier heated up, as the activist investor responded to a counteroffer by raising his bid.

summary: The FDA under Obama didn't push for a law to regulate drug-mixing pharmacies before a recent outbreak of more than 600 meningitis cases tied to such a pharmacy, the head of the agency said.

headline: Fannie, Freddie Losses in Libor Case May Top $3 Billion
summary: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac may have lost more than $3 billion as a result of banks' alleged manipulation of a key interest rate, an FHFA watchdog report said.

headline: RIM's Cash, Subscribers to Get Attention
summary: Despite Research In Motion's recently resurgent shares, investors are bracing for more bleak numbers when RIM reports quarterly results after markets close Thursday. They will also focus on two key metrics: cash and its BlackBerry subscriber base.

headline: Nike Locks in Oregon Tax Guarantee

headline: At Citigroup, a Move to Add Spring to Its Step
summary: The bank won't fill the post of president and chief operating officer, an attempt to become more nimble by eliminating layers of management.

headline: Macmillan Renegotiates E-Book Deals With Retailers
summary: Macmillan, the last of the major publishers still fighting the Justice Department over antitrust charges, says it has renegotiated its e-book deals with retailers to allow some discounting.

headline: Navistar Posts Loss, Lower Revenue
summary: Navistar reported a quarterly loss as warranty costs and a 24% drop in sales weighed on the commercial truck maker.

headline: More Doubts Arise Over Chávez's Health

headline: Chevron Closes In on  Argentine Shale Deal

summary: From the American Enterprise Institute  By John R. Bolton

summary: The boarded-up Hibernia Bank building, a 19th-century architectural jewel that once housed one of the oldest banking institutions in San Francisco, is set to be brought back to life.

summary: The extensive design required for producing specialized Legos, like the ones for "Star Wars" or this year's "The Hobbit," requires months of engineering. A behind-the-scenes look at the design and production process.

headline: Ramen on the Table,Jazz in the Background
summary: Downtown San Mateo is a haven for lovers of Japanese cuisine. Judging by the flocks at Himawari, the restaurant has found a sweet spot in the crowd.

headline: Vital Signs
summary: Silicon Valley counties are seeing much faster population growth than the state as a whole, according to a new analysis of U.S. Census data from the California Department of Finance.

headline: Senate GOP to Propose $24 Billion for Sandy Aid
summary: Senate Republicans will soon propose a $24 billion aid package for superstorm Sandy rebuilding efforts as an alternative to the $60 billion plan being pressed by Senate Democrats.

summary: So-called boomerang workers who return to their old employers after brief stints at once highflying startups are helping to reverse a trend in Silicon Valley.

summary: In today's pictures, Chinese recruits focus, firefighters honor Sandy Hook Elementary shooting victim Daniel Barden, a polio worker receives medical treatment in Pakistan, and more.

headline: ADM, Graincorp CEOs Square Off Over Bid
summary: GrainCorp CEO Alison Watkins will face investors at the company's annual meeting Thursday after Archer Daniels Midland sweetened its takeover offer to $2.95 billion.

headline: UBS Must Crack New Code
summary: UBS and other big banks find the synergies that made them so profitable are being dismantled. But the bigger threat may be that they are expected to behave better.

summary: Thomson Reuters named Reuters editor in chief Stephen Adler to run a new business unit combining Reuters' editorial and news-related marketing and sales.

headline: Treasurys Rally; Auction Gets Strong Demand
summary: Treasurys bounced back as buyers returned to the market and bid up a seven-year note auction, looking to take advantage of the recent price drop.

headline: Catalonia to Hold Vote on Independence
summary: Nationalist leaders in Catalonia agreed to form a new government and hold a referendum on independence for the wealthy region, maintaining a push for autonomy that poses a major challenge to Spain's central government.

headline: Yen Drops on 'Fiscal Cliff' Optimism
summary: The yen touched its lowest level against the dollar in more than eight months on optimism that negotiators in Washington were getting closer to a solution to avoid the "fiscal cliff."

headline: KFC Criticized Over Suppliers in China
summary: Yum Brands' KFC chain is feeling a backlash in China after a state-run TV broadcaster aired a program alleging that some local suppliers improperly used antibiotics in chickens.

headline: Canadian Dollar Down for Second Day
summary: The Canadian dollar moves slightly lower against the U.S. dollar for the second straight session, as traders began to unwind positions in the Canadian currency prior to the end of the year.

summary: Darden is building up a next generation of restaurants to take over its growth when the classic brands max out on expansion in the U.S. These smaller, trendier chains focus on bar business, live music and unique tastes.

headline: Prison Riot Kills 23 People in Mexico
summary: At least 23 people were killed in a bloody prison riot in the Mexican state of Durango, signaling challenges ahead for President Enrique Peña Nieto, who pledged this week to make taming crime his top priority.

headline: Tragedy Shifts Gun Debate
summary: The mass shooting in Connecticut appears to be reshaping the politics of gun control, with several ardent supporters of gun rights in Congress calling for steps to toughen the nation's weapons laws.

headline: New Calls for Gun Limits
summary: Several lawmakers Sunday called for reintroducing a ban on assault weapons in the wake of Friday's deadly school rampage. President Barack Obama is also likely to propose gun-policy changes, according to two administration officials.

headline: No Need for 'Balance' In Cutting the Deficit
summary: Sen. Rob Portman writes a thoughtful analysis of "A Truly Balanced Approach to the Deficit" (op-ed, Dec. 11). May I respectfully ask the senator to stop trying to be "balanced" and make recommendations that are truly intended to correct our destructive deficit

headline: Tax Rates and U.S. Competitiveness
summary: Peter  Schiff accurately depicts the reality of the high marginal tax rates of the post-World War II era and the lack of a deleterious economic effect ("The Fantasy of a 91% Top Income Tax Rate," op-ed, Dec. 7).

headline: Asbestos Victims Face Further Hardships
summary: Regarding your Dec. 12 editorial "Busting the Trust Fraud": The Ohio legislation you referenced will add substantially to the hardships of asbestos victims, who have already suffered tremendously.

headline: How Luxury Spending Helps Others Survive
summary: Betsey Martens of Boulder, Colo., writes that productive members of society should "forgo a dinner out or a new dress" in order to continue growing the federal government (Letters, Dec. 6). Really? Tell that to the clerks and owners of the dress shop and the busboys, cooks, wait staff and countless others at the restaurant. Such economic ignorance could doom this country.

headline: Fed Has Narrow Path Between Deflation and Inflation
summary: The Fed is attempting to navigate a narrow path between deflation and unanticipated inflation. Both must be prevented, and the former is arguably the bigger threat today.

headline: Supply Data Boost Oil Futures
summary: U.S. crude-oil futures rose to a two-month high after government data showed a jump in demand for diesel and heating oil.

headline: Toward a Single-Payer Health Plan
summary: There may very well be method to the ObamaCare madness if version 1.0 of government-mandated health care is a transitional step—or a "starter home," as Sen. Tom Harkin put it a few years ago ("It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad ObamaCare," Review & Outlook, Dec. 14)

headline: Sonoma Looks to Plunge Into Power Market
summary: Sonoma County is moving forward with a plan to form its own power agency, a project that over time, county officials say, will lower electricity bills and reduce dependence on fossil fuels.

headline: BBC Criticized in Savile Review
summary: The BBC's 2011 decision to not air an investigative report on a deceased BBC personality was "seriously flawed" but wasn't made "for any improper reason," or because of managerial pressure, a review concluded.

headline: Pulling No Punches at the Bell House
summary: With a droll delivery and a mischievous matter-of-factness about the mundanities of life, Todd Barry has established himself as one of the most distinctive stand-up comics in New York today.

headline: Whirlpool Scores Victory Against Washer Imports
summary: The U.S. Commerce Department found that makers of large residential washing machines in Mexico and South Korea have been selling their products in the U.S. at unfairly low prices and may be subject to duties.

headline: Facebook, Twitter Spar
summary: The battle lines are sharpening between Facebook and Twitter, as they fight to become the prime hub for photo sharing on the Internet.

headline: Natural-Gas Futures Settle 2.9% Lower
summary: Natural-gas futures resumed a recent weak pattern, falling nearly 3% ahead of a weekly inventory report that is expected to be bearish.

headline: Focus Media Board Approves Buyout Offer
summary: Nasdaq-listed Focus Media said its board approved an offer to take it private that values the Shanghai-based advertising firm at slightly more than US$3.7 billion, in what would be the largest-ever buyout of a Chinese company.

headline: GM Adds Premium Fuel to the Market
summary: GM's buyback of 40% of the U.S. Treasury's stake in the company sent its shares soaring.

headline: Asia Failed Them in 2012, But FX Investors Sticking With It
summary: If at first you don't succeed, try again. After seeing their big bets on an Asian rebound fall victim to a Chinese slowdown in 2012, investors are again gearing for a rally in the region's currencies as 2013 comes into view.

headline: Queen Elizabeth Land
summary: It now really can be said that the sun will never set on Her Majesty's domains.

headline: Pagoda-Style Living in Illinois
summary: This home in northern Illinois emphasizes its natural surroundings both inside and out, with a rubber tree growing in the living room.

headline: Pimco's Gross Cuts Back on MBS
summary: Bond guru Bill Gross is paring back one of the main trades that helped the world's biggest bond fund make an impressive comeback this year from its humiliating performance in 2011.

headline: Kleiner Partners' View of the Future of Tech
summary: John Doerr and Ted Schlein of venture-capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers discuss investments in tech and clean tech, as well as their thoughts on the "four horsemen" of the Web.

headline: Rebels Without a Clue
summary: The cypherpunks were prescient to warn us about Internet surveillance but they couldn't have found a worse leader than Julian Assange. Luke Allnutt reviews Julian Assange's "Cypherpunks" and Andy Greenberg's "This Machine Kills Secrets."

headline: Interest in Ukraine's Hryvnia Goes Cold
summary: Even seasoned emerging-market investors have to draw the line somewhere. And for most, the Ukrainian hryvnia has crossed to the wrong side.

headline: Game Maker THQ Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Videogame maker THQ filed for bankruptcy protection, and said its assets will be acquired by private equity firm Clearlake Capital for about $60 million.

headline: Gov. Malloy's 'Brutal Week'
summary: The massacre at an elementary school plunged Connecticut's first-term governor, Dannel Malloy, into an unfamiliar position: consoler of the grieving. "I haven't thought about much else but the firehouse," he said in an interview.

headline: BOE Reveals Carney Housing Allowance
summary: Incoming Bank of England Governor Mark Carney will be paid £250,000 a year ($406,300) in living expenses on top of his £624,000 a year salary.

headline: Obama Backs Push For New Gun Laws
summary: President Obama said all gun buyers should be subject to background checks and that he would push "without delay" ideas for remolding the nation's mental health and gun laws, setting up a potential fight with gun-rights advocates.

headline: For Some, Home=Office
summary: Some businesses are encouraging work from home, reflecting a push to cut costs as well the effect of cheap, reliable and fast communications, writes David Wessel.

headline: Army Orders Review of Hiring at All Its Day-Care Centers
summary: The Army has ordered a review of hiring practices at all of its day-care centers world-wide after an investigation at a Virginia center found that background checks hadn't been properly conducted on employees there.

headline: Two Former UBS Traders Charged in Libor Probe
summary: Tom Hayes and Roger Darin were charged with conspiring to manipulate a key global interest rate.

headline: Brazil Real Strengthens to 1-Month High

headline: Ally Financial Repays $4.5 Billion of Debt
summary: The final U.S. Treasury note auction of 2012 drew an eager crowd as investors both at home and abroad took advantage of the market's recent price drop.

headline: Greek Bonds Rally After S&P Upgrade
summary: Greece's bond market got two reasons to rally as a ratings upgrade was followed by news that the European Central Bank would again accept Greek government debt as collateral.

headline: South Korea Elects First Woman Leader
summary: South Koreans elected conservative lawmaker Park Geun-hye to be their next president, making her the first woman to lead the country.

headline: Kodak to Sell Patents for $525 Million
summary: Eastman Kodak said a consortium has agreed to pay about $525 million to acquire and license the company's patents, helping the one-time photography giant move closer to its goal of emerging from bankruptcy.

headline: Camaro Production to Move to Michigan
summary: General Motors plans to move production of its Chevrolet Camaro sports car to Michigan from Canada as part of a cost-cutting move.

headline: Budget News Aids European Stocks
summary: The euro reached an eight-month high against the dollar following a five-notch upgrade of Greece by ratings firm Standard & Poor's, and investors welcomed progress in the U.S. budget negotiations, prompting a rise in stocks.

headline: Billabong Shares Tumble
summary: Australian surfwear maker Billabong received a fifth takeover bid the same day it slashed its profit forecast, sending its shares plummeting.

summary: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia said its recently appointed chief executive, Lisa Gersh, plans to step down after a transition period. Ms. Gersh had been promoted to the job in July.

headline: Sirius Names Interim CEO
summary: Sirius XM Radio named James E. Meyer as interim chief executive, succeeding Mel Karmazin.

headline: Getco Maps Out Post-Knight Crusade
summary: Top executives of newly combined company outline their plans for a new type of global trading firm.

headline: Singapore Soars in Private Banking
summary: A rapid increase in the number of Asia's rich and a crackdown on Switzerland as a tax haven is making Singapore the newest private-banking hub for the world's wealthy.

headline: UBS's Libor Communications
summary: See a Commodity Futures Trading Commission document that gives "examples of misconduct from written communications" involving UBS.

headline: Bonds Beware Central Bank Regime Change
summary: Bond yields remain calm despite signs of an apparent revolution in monetary policy. Investors may be wise to be more concerned.

headline: Japanese Deals Likely To Keep Flowing
summary: The big change next year could be an increased push for M&A at home as well as abroad, as companies struggle to make domestic operations sleeker and more competitive.

headline: Oracle's Not-So-Peppy Growth
summary: Oracle's shareholders should take a closer look at the company's reported earnings. Like its big tech brethren, it is relying on nonoperational items to boost earnings per share.

headline: Advisers Scour Client Portfolios Amid Gun Furor
summary: A client called financial adviser John Burke this week seeking to buy just the type of stocks the planner dislikes -- those of gun manufacturers. Another financial adviser is anticipating that some clients may want to sell such stocks and is now reviewing clients' portfolios.
